All my out of town visitors are brought here for drinks, followed by dinner next door. I'm always happy when the wait at Chow is long, because it means more time at Pilsner!

This is one of the nicest pubs in town, great atmosphere, jukebox, staff, pinball, pool, smoking patio (for whatever you like to smoke), and penguins. Most "Sports Bars" in this world would kill to be able to duplicate this ambiance. Window seats are a bonus for people watching along Church. 

On busy nights the bar out back is open too. I like to watch Midwestern or Texan people's faces when it dawns on them that they're in a 'gasp' GAY BAR! Then they immediately realize it's not so bad after all and that Reverend John Piggy (Hagee) is a lying fuck. This is also a great place for unthreatened straight guys to meet the fag hag of their dreams (if only for one night). 

Seriously, if I lived nearby this would be my only hangout. I imagine this is what Castro bars must've been like in the old days before people like Les Natali had their way.
author: stephan k.

description: Throwing back Hoegaarden while playing pinball is a ridiculous way to end the most nervous night.
author: Fish F.

description: The Pilsner Inn was a great place to hang out with friends during a birthday party. Unfortunately the bartender Tommy was not friendly and made the bar not fun for anyone. Maybe he just had a bad day but the other staff refereed to him as "Grumpy". Get over it Tommy you are a bartender and you job is to make the customers happy. We would have had a much better time if Tommy wasn't working.
author: Dustin W.

description: I like Pilsner because my 32" waist isn't considered extra large as it is at many of the other gay bars in castro. I like Pilsner because of the outdoor patio where I can get some fresh air and enjoy a long conversation with a friend or total stranger. I like Pilsner because the drinks are affordable and usually poured heavy. I like Pilsner because of the Puffin-themed decor that seemingly makes no sense. I like Pilsner because Pilsner likes me.
author: Wayne F.

description:
holy crap?!?! this is a gay bar?!?!? i was at a gay bar? 

now it make sense. there WERE a lot of bald headed dudes there. 

loved the patio area.

watermelon beer on tap? nice.
author: Euge L.

description:
Oh, Pilsner. Home-away-from-home; Desi to my Lucy; mother, brother, secret lover. If going to the Pilsner at the exclusion of all other bars is wrong, I don't want to be right. Except I'm totally right, because the Pilsner rules. 

Consider the facts: it has the nicest, hottest, hard-drink-pourinest bartenders in town. The patrons are (generally) local and polite. They have a wide variety of high quality beers and liqour, served with a smile. 

Do they have a patio on which to smoke? Why yes, yes they do. That is where you will find me most waking hours. Do they treat smokers like pariahs? Why, no, they do not. They (shockingly) understand that some people like to have a little nicotine with their liver damage. They will even empty your ashtray for you if you ask nicely. What's not to love? 

Pilsner is a great bar, with cheap drinks, a friendly staff, and a neighborhood atmosphere that is unpretentious. It is literally where everybody knows my naaaa-aaame. And they're always glad I caaaa-aaame. 

Come by for a drink sometime! Just don't sit at my table.
author: Noelle H.

description:
I love the Pilsner for what it is: a low-key nonpretentious gay bar that you can take straight friends to or just relax.  

Drink:  There are a good number of beers on tap.  Beer is reasonably priced although not dirt cheap.  They have wines by the glass, but I stay away from it here.

Vibe: The best seats are in the window alcoves which seat ~5 people and gives a nice view on to the street. There is a great back patio for when the weather is warm.   Music from the juke box is generally okay to good.

Also, they have the strangest penguin theme if you look around at some of the art and statues on the walls.  Sometimes I try to figure out if this is a joke or whether the owner just has a penguin obsession.
author: Jeff A.

description:
Great great place! And I work next door and live down the street, so I get to frequent this place. Truly a neighborhood bar.  The kind of place where you know the bartenders(heart them all!), know all the regulars, had a few too many after a break up, have good fun times with a group of friends at the picnic table on the back patio (BEAUTIFUL PATIO), got kicked out at closing time, but felt the love! LOL 

Always a good crowd, cute, and friendly, fun, great place to hang with your neighbors.
author: Scott H.

description:
Finally a gay bar where I feel comfortable. By fairly random chance, I ended up here 4 times in one week, enjoying the remarkably different crowds that can be found on different nights. The patio is comfortable, even on Saturday night, the crowd isn't too overwhelming, and most of the people I've met have been friendly.

The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars was the night I was there at closing time. First, a guy walks through the patio announcing "patio closes in 10 minutes." So, figuring I had time, I lit up one last cigarette. No sooner had I done so than another employee starts announcing "patio closes in 5 minutes." By the time I'd taken my third puff off the cigarette, the first employee had turned to my friends and I and said, "we're closing the patio now, can I get you to head back into the bar?"

When I shot back, "I thought we had 10 minutes left." The guy said, "nope, we're clearing it out now." I said, "I lit this cigarette when you announced ten minutes." "Well, you can smoke it up front right next to the entrance to the bar. We just want to get people moving because it will take us 10 minutes to get everyone out." Riiiiiiiight. I glanced around and saw a total of 5 other people left on the patio. Yup, clearly an unreasonable mob who would be stubborn and impossible to move. Yeah, I get that they were anxious to get out of there and end their shifts, but talk to me like an adult. Say, "we're closing the patio now" in the first place, rather than this "10 minutes" crap. I wouldn't have complained if they hadn't made a misleading announcement.
author: Jere K.

description:
A down to earth and unpretentious bar. 

It is at a convenient location for non-drivers because you could take buses, street cars and Muni to get there.  The parking could be difficult from early evening on because it is located on Church and Market.  Try finding parking on Delores Street.

This is another option when you want to get away from the Castro which is walking distant (10 minutes).

It is also a nice place to have a drink while you wait for a table at Chows (which is a nice restaurant next door).
author: SFGAM d.

description:
Yes, its a gay bar and, no, I'm straight.  Though I have been offered free drinks by hopeful gay San Franciscans, I don't ever feel the atmosphere of predation that I do in many Castro pubs.  

I've lived near this joint for almost 2 years and it has become my neighborhood hangout.  The bartenders here and extremely competent and attentive (their long-islands are surprisingly good compared to bars like Dalva's and Double Dutch ... ie delicious but toxic) and I have been able to give back the wrong beers, even on busy nights.  If you live with or date a smoker (I sadly deal with both), there is a back yard area that always has a seat and allows smokers to indulge their habit without disappearing every 20 minutes and there no TVs back there!!  

Don't bother with the pool table ... its always busy and the pinball machines are rigged in my opinion, especially that damned Monopoly one.  Keep your eyes open for deals and special events; because the prices are a little above average and this place is really worth experiencing when discounts are available.
author: Justin T.

description: Penguins. Testosterone. Penguins. Nicely made but pricey drinks. Penguins. Play Lotto here! Penguins. Pool table in use. Penguins. Nice patio. Penguins. Stoic but not unpleasant bartender. Penguins. Ladies room key on a big metal spoon. Penguins. Too beautiful a day to stay long. Buh-bye penguins.
author: Poet D.

description:
I came here for DYL a few weeks back. Not bad, but not great. The back garden/patio area seemed nice, but it was a bit crowded, even though it was only 6:30. The bartenders' attention was a bit difficult to get (for a bunch of us, not just me), but they also didn't charge me for my club soda like some other places do.

I guess I'd go back, if someone wanted me to meet him/her there, but with so many other bars in this city, I won't be rushing back.
author: Katie I.

description:
Where can you:

wait for a table to dine in a different establishment
gawk at men with men
watch sports
buy lottery tickets
ask for the bathroom key, and the key chain is the cumulative size of Rhode Island
sing ABBA
play pool

It's a good time. Bring your friends.
author: Rene D.

description:
Pilsner is a great place to grab a beer, hang out, and talk when you kinda want to do Castro, but don't. They have a great random jukebox and selection of beers on tap. Just take the plunge and get a pitcher if you plan to be there awhile.

Smokers or no, the patio is nice and inviting... wonderful to just sit and kibbitz for awhile. But seriously, why does the inside have to smell like feet?
author: Aaron L.

description:
A gay sport's bar? Who da thunk it? But yet it exists. The patio is really nice when the weather is good. It's spacious, covered, and well landscaped. I have less favorable opinions of the inside of the bar. It feels divey and uncomfortable. 

The drinks are decently priced, but I sort of hate it when bars charge $3.75 rather than $4 for a beer. Yes, it's cheaper, but then I feel the urge to tip with the quarter and keep the dollar for myself. Totally evil of me, I know. 

I'm not gay, but in terms of the dating scene for my gay friends, it's a good spot. The gay guys are usually more friendly and less lecherous, but still hit on my friends, and for the gay ladies, there are lots of lesbians there on days when the weather is nice.
author: Netty L.

description:
So long Transfer and hello Pilsner!

It appears that if I'm in need of a beer in the neighborhood and don't want  to hit up Haight Street, I'll now be frequenting the Pilsner. Great outdoor patio, nice casual crowd, friendly bartenders and no stinky bathrooms. Huge plus for the fact that it's a gay bar and a comfortable one at that. No pretense here. Get a beer, relax and catch up with your friends.


ps. Even if The Transfer does get a facelift, I refuse to frequent a place called The Bar on Church. Bad move, BOC.
author: Corey F.

description:
Best gay bar I've been to in the city hands down, or up, or wherever you wanna put them. They have a good selection of beer on tap, cute penguins on the walls (anyone know why?? ), and cheap beer.

The crowd here was very diverse, unlike most bars in the Castro. We weren't the only non-gay men there!! I love gay men though.. I'm putting that out there. Who else will tell you "you have a wonderful pony tail" when you need to hear it? Also, there were a interesting group of gay clowns (actual clowns) which made for interesting conversations. 

I really like the outdoor area and the little fish pond, but wish it would have been heated because it was a bit cold to stand outside. Next time I go to the 'stro for happy hour I'm going here!
author: Sarah W.

description: I had a bitter fight here with my best gay friend a number of years ago (over whether the Inner and Outer Mission is contiguous. Ahem, it is not). The friendship has persisted and I'm glad I had chance to go back and rid myself of the bad memories by knocking down pitchers on a sunny day in the patio.  It's a mixed crowd. There's long benches along the wall and we scored the picnic bench. There's also a metal table with three plastic chairs.  Pitchers, $15 for premium beer.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Love this place for a beer. Good place to grab a beer after work and chill. 

Very low key which I love.. its more about having a beer and talking with friends.

:-)
author: Art A.

description:
I love the non-Castro-y feel of the Pilsner.  It's laid back and comfortable with a good eclectic mix of different kinds of music on the juke box.  

The back patio is a big draw too.  I've spent hours hanging with friends.  I've seen people who saunter out into the back with a beer and a book and settle in for some down time alone.
author: Jen I.

description:
I've been obsessing over Fat Tire Amber Ale lately.  Yeah, yeah, yeah, I know it's the trendy beer du jour, but still -- it tastes really good, and that lovely amber color.  Plus the fact that New Belgium Brewing is a very eco-friendly company.

So, I go down to the Pilsner Inn for a couple of reasons.  It's a gay bar that's very straight friendly.  They show sports games on the televisions.  And they have a wonderful selection of beers on tap.  I love that about them.  Well, and the fact that the bartenders are hot doesn't hurt, either.

Plus, I can have a few beers and walk the ten minute trek up over Mint Hill to my flat in Hayes Valley and only see one or two pink elephants!
author: Paul B.

description:
Three stars alone for the lack of pretension, which is always great for a bar. However, one of their bartenders threw some serious attitude to my friend over drink prices. Hello buddy, but if your specials board is advertising $4 Absolut and you try to charge $5, you're going to hear about it, so admit your mistake and back down. 

Aside from that, another star off for the overall bathroom theme that pervades this place. Toilet paper on the floor that sticks to your shoe and makes you look like as ass? Check! No door on the men's room so you can see them all, ahem, doing their business into a large trough? Check!

That said, it's nice to see Hoegaarden on tap and keep those $4 cocktails flowing.
author: Carla C.

description:
Ooh, this place was FUN! I almost wish I was a gay man because they really know how to have fun - I try and I try, but I'm just not going to grow a willy or get into girls that much. 

Wish they had a better beer selection, though.
author: Mi M.

description:
Wow. What a fantastic and amazing bar. I'm not gay and I was well aware that this was a gay establishment but as me and the fiance walked past it looked very inviting. We sat down and ordered some very cheap beers. Excellent prices all around. White Russians were 7 a piece.

Great conversations with people we didn't even know. Awesome locations (right next to MUNI church street subway).

not too busy. It's cash only so that's a drag.
author: Adam C.

description:
THE BEST BAR in San Francisco, hands down.  They have great bartenders, a rockin jukebox, and a very cool patio with plants.
Does anyone know of an equivalent in LA?
author: Lisa M.

description:
One night, after a day of drinking at the beach, a friend and I went to the Pilsner.  We *both* fell off the benches and into the garden in back on the patio.  Lost my sunglasses -- and they were still there the next morning when I sulked in to check!

Also, soooo much fun to hang out and play pinball on any sort of afternoon.

For that, I will always love the Pilsner!

However...I find the drinks a little on the pricey side...
author: Dwayne A.

description:
It can be a little bit of a loud space in certain parts of the bar (hard to talk to others) but it's cute. Very "homey feeling" and welcoming. Plus, they got my Wyder's Cider (pear flavored) and I love that some goodness, ya know?!

Check it out. It's a good place to go if you want to just relax and hang out...not one of the places that you might want to visit if you are looking for some place to "be seen" (because everyone here could care less who is there...they're all just relaxed.)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
worst bar in the city.  i'm not gay but i used to stop in to grab a beer since i live close by.  they used to treat me like garbage because i dared walk into a gay establishment with my girlfriend.  it was like oh no, she has a vagina.  well, mr. bartender from redneck land your in cali now.  women live here too as well as do straight men.  don't be threatened because i dared walk into your establishment with a woman.  i thought this was sf where we accept everyone!  go back to your redneck land and see how you like it there.    

another major drawback is the men's bathroom.  i know it's a gay bar but leaving the door open and putting mirrors over the toilets so the bartenders can check out the dudes while they are pissing should be a crime.  it might be.  

one final drawback is all the pot smoking in back.  ah pilsner.. you can't smoke in bars anymore, why do you think smoking pot is ok?  stupid place, bitchy bartenders, terrible service = TOTAL SHIT HOLE!
author: T D.

description:
Fun Bar with lots of gay men. We had alot of people meet of there because: 1) central location 2) Large outside garden patio where you can smoke and 3) I don't know what three is but you need things in threes!

Drinks: standard and moderately priced
Location: Central with a beautiful garden
People: All 30-50 gay men
Did I just repeat myself?
author: Rory V.

description:
All time San Francisco favorite. Too many lost evenings accrued there. Although it can get very crowded, and quite intrusively noisy, it's a great local romp and a convenient location to and from your nightlife.
Long bar, pool table, outdoor smoking patio...so cosmopolitan in a dive. Make friends with the bartenders, hooked up for life.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
when did the bartenders dictate the tips they get?
i guess today was it.

as I left the bar the bartender said i left change on counter. i replied it was for him. he countered its an insult, my reply, i see you only take dollar or over for tip.

you'd think anyone would take money when they can get it. 

this occurred today wednesday afternoon 3:30

buzz cut hair, brown, small framed white boy.

dont go there this time of day.

He's a pig
author: Mike L.

description:
Of all the bars I visited during my vacation in San Francisco, the Pilsner Inn is my favorite.  The outdoor patio is beautiful and spacious, though if there's not much breeze it can get a little smoky.  Inside is a friendly atmosphere, a pool table, and several pinball machines.  The rotating lineup of beer and drink specials, is great, especially for a fan of draught beer like myself.  Friendly bartenders and a prime location right in front of a stop for the J Muni line, with Market St. just around the corner, round out the Pilsner's charm.

It never got crowded, even on Saturday night, which was half the appeal, given the small size of most San Francisco gay bars.
author: Scott S.

description: My friends like this place a lot more than I do - just not really my scene.  The only way I can describe it is to say that it always feels "dirty" - and no, not in the fun "dirty" kind of way.  Parking is dreadful so definitely take a cab or Muni.  Drinks are good and the patio in the back is nice.  People always tell me they go to Pilsner because it is something different - I must be missing something.
author: prior O.

description: This is pretty cool laid back bar in the Castro where you can get a beer and not have to fend off an attack from people just looking to go home and f***.   Not that there is anything wrong with that.
author: Chris D.

description: This is a funny little bar. Some say it is a gay bar. I say it is more of a waiting room for dinner at Chow on most busy nights. It is also a smoking lounge to save you from the harsh San Francisco wind tunnel that is Church Street (they have a fairly sheltered back patio). You get a complete cross culture in here. I have seen it all....including things I didn't ask to see since the mens bathroom is pretty damn exposed on many nights, leaving the men pretty damn exposed as well.
author: Drue C.

description: Forget waiting here before Chow, cause Chow, well, blows. But the Pilsner is a great gay bar that actually has a little thing called ROCK N ROLL on the jukebox and decent drink prices and, and, wait for it, A PATIO! I wish all those pathetic souls waiting for Chow's food would wait somewhere else, thank you.
author: patrick g.

description: As one of those 'pathetic souls' waiting for a table at Chow, I find the atmosphere here to be less oppressive than in most gay bars, maybe because the majority of the clientele appears to be here for socializing rather than heavy cruising. I've been known to return after dinner to relax on the patio out back, wondering if there's anything more pathetic than someone who feels the need to call others pathetic, simply because they don't share his inexplicably bad opinion of the outstanding restaurant next door.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Pilsner is great.  There's no pretense and the guys are actually hot.  Not hot in a primped out Castro kind of way, but hot in an I've got nothing to prove kind of way.  Also the men here are not recently turned 21.  Thank god.  The back patio is about as good as it gets for outdoor drinking.  It's always quiet enough to hold a conversation, but it's never boring.  The diverse crowd sees to that.  Just sipping a beer in back and eavesdropping can keep me entertained.   Also, I think I've actually had more conversations with strangers here than anywhere else in the city.  Ultimately that's the reason you go out, right?   Otherwise we'd all drink at home.  So yeah, Pilsner's where it's at.
author: Ben R.

description: The Pilsner is one of my favorite spots to meet up with old friends after work.  It's got a diverse atmosphere, the staff is friendly and if you like beer they have a lot.  My favorite thing about it, though, is the back patio which on a nice day is a real treat especially for San Francisco.
author: Sean O.

description: WHAT?! A bar near Castro where peopel don't stand around as though they're about to audition for Vogue magazine??!! NO!! IT'S IMPOSSIBLE!! I DON'T BELIEVE IT! Well, believe it or not it's here. Pilsner Inn is a great chillin' bar with a patio where YOU CAN SMOKE! Not a scene bar, you're a bear? You're into leather? Are you a twinky? A 56 year-old jock? Everyone is welcome here! The drinks are reasonably priced too. See ya' there!
author: Javier G.

description: I've been going to the Pilsner off and on for many years and it has always been consistently a good place to meet friends, chill out and catch up. The bar is very unpretentious and friendly. The crowd is very diverse. The music comes entirely from a jukebox which is fine. The only downfall is that is off the beaten path from the Castro, but kind of gives it it's unique quality. Its not like Badlands, Midnight Sun or even Moby Dicks.
author: Clive L.

description:
Since my regular fave neighborhood bar Amber died, I come here now.

It's a mixed crowd somedays, pool table is a bonus.

The smoking patio is roomy, and often packed on nice days.

This is a decent place to hang, and I used to come here more often back when (those of u who live in the neighborhood know what I'm talking about)

There was a restaurant called Hong Kong, i soooo terribly miss that place!

But I'd hit the pilsner after a huge bowl of chow mein.

Also, it's pretty rad during football season on Sundays. If u r into that sorta thing
author: Kristin Z.

description: Great place.  Relaxed, friendly and comfortable.  I've never seen it too crowded or too empty.  I usually run in to a bunch of old friends here as the place invites hanging around, while kind of repelling attitude at the door.  The patio is lovely even if you don't smoke.  I also have a bit of a soft spot for for the intricate and titillating but ultimately harmless rituals surrounding trough urinals.  Ha.  Half a star off (I rounded down, sorry) for not being really EXCITING.
author: Scott K.

description: Chill environment with no attitude - a definite respite from the sights and sounds of the Castro.  It has a nice patio out back, and a number of tvs that were tuned to football, not cheesy dance music videos, the last time I was there.
author: GeneR S.

description:
First, I am surprised that this place is described by others as nothing but a gay bar. True, most of the clientele are guys and, true again, most of them are probably gay - dunno... don't ask... but to me this is a drinking dive first and a gay bar second. (It should be said that I have tried to clarify my position on this as I have taken some heat for daring to suggest that this is not a gay bay. I guess I am just saying that it is not one of those scary gay bars where the gayness is jammed down your throat.)
Second, I am surprised that there are so few reviews for this place - although, perhaps not... it's never that crowded - in all the times I have ever been in there, there has always been a full bar, but plenty of places to sit or stand and down a few with friends. Not sure why that is, given the convenient location - but I am not complaining - more room for me and mine.
Last - I love this place - this is a easy-going, relaxed place to have a few drinks. Park in Safeway's car park for a couple of hours, order a Newcastle Brown Ale, go out on the patio, and pass the time or catch up with friends. Nice.
author: Kingpin X.

description: Nothing about Pilsner Inn really stands out, except perhaps the relative lack of pilsners on tap. However the outdoor seating is really nice, great place for a drink on a warm SF day! The bartenders are all very nice, and they do pour very generous drinks at very reasonable prices. There are plenty of places to sit, and it wasn't overly crowded on a Friday night. Either I'm blind, or this place really is super "straight friendly" because I didn't realize it was a gay bar! If I was in the neighborhood and wanted a drink, Pilsner Inn would definitely rank highly on my list.
author: Will A.

description: Sorry to say that I've experienced discrimination here.  If your straight or just not outwardly gay, you will have trouble getting a drink. I sat at a bar with not other customers for over 15 min for a beer because I am not a hip, gay lesbian..or cute guy.  I felt hostility when we finally got served.  Weird, If the straight community acted like this..where would we be?.. oh well
author: M L.

description:
this place is great for the things it *doesn't* have:

- no pathetic excuse for a dance floor.

- no shitty music blasting on a pathetic excuse for a dance floor.

- no cover required to get in the door to try to muscle your way to the pathetic excuse for a dance floor to be assaulted by blasting shitty music.

- no line outside you have to wait in to pay to get in the door to try to muscle your way to the pathetic excuse for a dance floor to be assaulted by blasting shitty music.

just a cool little pub with a nice patio out back, laid-back atmosphere, a pool table and an overall aversion to pretense.

bring some friends, grab some beers, head out back to the patio and have some good times together.
author: Mark B.

description:
I don't know about this one.
I used to like it. I used to hang out there with friends. There seemed to be a nice, laid back crowd. Attractive in a non-Vogue (to reference an earlier review) and fun. It seems that every time I have been lately, the clientele is spotty at best and the music choices are downright awful. And, is just me or does this please always feel a little dirty, (and not in the good way)? Hmm. And then there was the night I saw the bartender punch one of the patrons. Oh well, not my scene anymore I guess. As they say in New England "takes all kines...takes all kines [sic]."
And while I'm at it, can't we have someplace that has a NON-SMOKING patio? There are people who like to sit outside with a drink and enjoy the fresh air - not inhale second-hand smoke. I know, I know - the persecuted smoker and all that. Whatever - move to Des Moines then you can smoke wherever you like. (No offense meant to lovely Des Moines)
author: Jamie M.

description: Cool bar, mixed crowd and good jukebox. Drinks were strong and the staff was very personable. Laidback vibe all around. Also can drink and smoke simultaneously. A rare treat in the city.
author: Jerry M.

description: This is still one of my favorite hangouts on a warm sunny afternoon or a rainy cold day. I always have a good time just sitting with my friends or reading a book. The staff is always great.
author: Travis H.

description: Great bar.  Nice outdoors seating. Nice window seating for watching the street.  Friendly and attentive bartender.  Cool scene/crowd of folks.  Yes, lots of gay men.  No, no pressure to be gay to be there.  I will definitely be coming back.  Also sports screens, but I don't care.  Also pool table, which I do care about.  Overall yay!
author: Heidi P.

description: I love this place.  I'm so sick of the Castro becoming yuppified - all of my old favorite joints have been ruined (Badlands, Detour, etc) but this place still rocks.  The bartenders are all nice (and cute, especially Warren), there is NO attitude, and people are way laid back.  Plus there's a patio so you can smoke...
author: Jay L.

description: Your neighborhood bar where everyone knows your name....maybe it's time I find another place.  Very friendly bar, great service, LOVELY patio in the back for smoking, and often some good games of pool going on.  A very nice escape from the typical Castro crowd.
author: Sean M.

description: I love the Pilsner. It's laid-back and unpretentious, and the drinks are stong and cheap. Cute guys, too. And they have a great patio.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description: My best friend, god bless him, loves to drag me around to the gay joints around town. Unfortunately, as a breeder these joints all seem to fall into two categories for me: (a) two dimensional trite characterizations of what a gay bar/club "should" be --think Cher/Madonna/random assorted bad dance music-- or (b) a grope scene (sugar, I'll let you know if I want you to touch). So, when we recently dropped into Pilsner for the first time I found the place to be a breath of fresh air despite being a sports bar. The jewel here is obviously the outdoor patio out back, but even inside (the few times I've now been) the place has a low key/laid back mixed friendly crowd (like the lounge Lush). Contrary to another review or two on here I found the drink prices to be on the lower end. The downside? I found the pinball machines to be a tease... the table we played had craptacular action.
author: Rob S.

description: Totally my neighborhood bar.  A great place to go to avoid the typical Castro crowd and bring your hetero friends for a level playing field.  My co-workers are actually the ones usually suggesting to go here for a happy hour on Friday afternoons so it's gotta be good for something.
author: Matt S.

description:
definitely my style gay bar.  it's so nice to hang out in a place that's not jammed with posers (unless everyone there is posing as a non-poser). the heavy-pour drink specials are easy on the wallet and at least a couple of the bartenders are easy on the eyes. it's never been jampacked when i've been there, and that's a definite plus.

how refreshing to have a non-scene gay bar that's not a bear bar (though everyone is clearly welcome). yay for pilsner.
author: Sidney B.

description: When I moved into the inner Mission area in 1995, the Pilsner Inn was not a popular place. Over the years, and particularly after the smoking laws changed and Chow opened next door to it, it turned that corner. It has a CD jukebox, pool tables with decent, friendly competition, and a very good outdoor courtyard that accommodates smokers and non. Heat lamps help ward off the cool SF nights.
author: Jim G.

description: Had my first date here with the last good bf. This was back when it was pretty diverse crowd wise. He won me a stuffed spider in the long gone steel arm fluffy creature game....wtf are those things called? Anyhow, I like the back patio, I only go with good friends and always have a nice time convincing myself I am not a 'fag hag'. Am a bit put off by the $5 Stella, but the bar staff is so quick and right on it and the bar back is Superman quick to come to your aide with a towel when your drunk friend spills his lemontastic Hefeweizen in your eye.
author: Colleen B.

description: The Pilsner has definitely become my new fave gay bar. Nice mellow vibe most of the time, great selection of beers (Gotta try the Moose Drool!) and usually friendly staff. But really, it's all about the patio. I, of course, remember the good ole days when it was entirely different, but hell, for a place to hang out, drink a beer, have a cigarette and have a conversation with someone that you can actually hear, you can't beat the Pilsner.
author: Stephen S.

description: Whenever i go, I'm surprised how they've remodeled the patio. Whether or not they've actually made changes to said patio remains to be seen, but I'll tell you one thing, they mix those drinks pretty strong.
author: Andrew H.

description: They let a straight guy like me hang out and play pinball - a fully restored Indiana Jones table - what more could you want. Someone will need to explain the mirrors above the urinal to me - what's that all about?
author: hunter w.

description: I'm definitely a fan of this place especially Mike who has been a bartender here since I have been going for the past few years.  I moved away for a bit to southern CA and came back and still come here for a few drinks.  He's always a gent and happily to help my friends and I.  He always remembers what I order even if I haven't come in for several weeks. Again, hit this place up if you want a low key hangout and a drink.
author: Jay S.

description: Can't say much for the inside but this is a great spot to grab a beer while waiting for a table at Chow.  Just make sure you head out back to enjoy that brew on the awesome patio.
author: Kyla B.

description: because there was a 10-15 min wait for a table at Chow's next door, our hostess suggested we can wait at the Pilsner and have her fetch us when our table would be ready. It was packed inside and it was too windy to wait outside, so off to the Pilsner we went. I ordered a pint of Sam Adams to sip leisurely for the 10-15 minutes we'd be in there but as soon as our pints arrived, our hostess walks in and says our table is ready! She noticed the full pints in front of us and said "I can get you in 10 minutes when you're ready." and so we had some time to enjoy our beer while we anticipated ginger cake. haha. The bartender was friendly and the beer was cheap and i left a little tipsy after leaving my tip on the counter, yah-yuh
author: kristin e.

description: While the inside of this Castro spot feels like a sports-bar with lot of unwanted neon signs, the beer-garden in back is a wonderful little oasis.  A great spot to have a beer on a warm night before getting dinner at Chow next door (if you're waiting for a table at Chow, this is the way to go.  The hostess/host at Chow will come get you in the garden when your table's ready).
author: Debbie A.

description: As an avid pinball nerd, and a fan of relaxed bars, I find The Pilsner Inn to be the best possible bar. They have three pinball machines, and a wonderful patio out back for smokers, friends of smokers and fans of the outdoors. My favorite thing about the Pilsner is the relaxed atmosphere. It doesn't feel like a meat market, nor are the other customers unfriendly. People are friendly, and kind and seem to be having a good time.
author: Jordan E.

description: Great centrally located local bar, gay bar, yes, but hetero friendly.  They don't have happy hour ( I asked) but they have regular specials all the time.  Great outdoor patio with a fish pond, plants, tables and overhang.  Inside, there is a pool table and juke box.  It's never really packed, but always has great service and proximity to Chow is a bonus.
author: regina k.

description: I've had many nights sitting on the wooden bench by the front window or outside in the patio with my gayboyfriends where I've wanted to slit my wrists. I dunno, call it a morose vibe at the Pils. But, regardless, it's a fairly cool spot where you can smoke and drink in a nice backyard patio. Although what the hell did they do to the patio? Now it has a lame hippie-esque floor with benches where you can only sit on one level (you used to be able to sit on two levels). It sucks, but it's still okay. If you're an abercrombie boy into similar you'll like it.
author: Liss C.

description: The Pilsner's patio is my happy place.  And Warren's chesticles are spectacular, as are his martinis.
author: LeSLiE W.

description: Meh. A good place to meet up with friends for a drink before heading out to other adventures, given its central location and proximity to Church Street MUNI. Also a good place to take your straight friends when they're visiting  town, because it feels like a gay bar, but isn't too slick (e.g., Badlands), and you won't have to worry about anything unusual happening. But therein lies its weakness too: as a destination of its own, I'd say it lacks a little texture. I mean, it's not like everybody's white, but everybody is pretty vanilla. Of course I realize this is exactly its selling point for 99% of all people.
author: Deano M.

description: A friend took us here, claiming it as one of her favorites. It's a pretty chill bar, great for hanging out and chatting away, specifically the back patio (as long as cigarette smoke doesn't bother you). Should I start the term "straight-friendly"? Hell, beer does not discriminate in my book.
author: Maximillian M.

description: 3 Stars for being a pretty good dive bar.  But they earned 4 stars for a beautiful outdoor patio in the back.  The vibe to me at least, was Castro meets the mission.  The drink specials were also something I noticed...cause they were cheap!! And god knows I love cheap drinks ;) I will definitely be back.
author: Amanda P.

description:
Pretty low key place.

Long lines for drinks and the quality of the drink strongly depended on the bartender.

I was there for St. Paddy's day. The crowd's age distribution was definitely peaking somewhere between 35-45.

The venue smelled kinda bad overall.

A nice little alley-ish patio on the back is great for smokers.
author: Jan M.

description:
GREAT BAR! Get off the subway, grab some dinner, stop at Safeway and then mosey on in to Pilsner. Friendly staff. Mike is a great bartender, especially on a game night. Warren is the best bartender you'll ever want to meet. The best! He can make your lousy day dissolve before your even knock back that first vodka.
Great jukebox. Pool and darts. And a window booth for boy watching.

(And by great jukebox, I mean a hangout bar with hangout music. Dance music is great -- in a dance bar. Gay men like, and listen to, music beyond dance. No, really, they do. And Pilsner knows it.)
author: Dennis C.

description:
there's just no better way to relax than sitting down to a good book and good beer, surrounded by orchids, chain smoking outside. weekday afternoons at the pilsner offer just this particular brand of bliss. you're guaranteed to be one of 2-4 customers, and, if you're a girl, no one will ever bother talking to you.

peace.

so difficult to find. so readily available here.

(more general comments: bartenders are very laid back and very nice, pours are decent but unspectacular, regulars are friendly, pool games are constant but competition relaxed. the pilsner gets packed on sunny weekend afternoons and some evenings, when the bulk of this review just does not apply.)
author: jen s.

description: I like this place a lot.  I can't say that I love it, even though I can stumble home in five minutes and it has good beer specials everyday.  The bar is low-key and thankfully there is usually no euro pop or techno pulsing.  The jukebox is good, but the electronic dart board is bunk. Be prepared for a daddy and/or daddy bear vibe and a smattering of straight ladies.   Great patio for smoking, but no sun really gets in because of weird plants hanging overhead.  Overall, the bar isn't super exciting, but its a fun and unpretentious neighborhood hangout for gays and those who love them.
author: David D.

description: Nice atmosphere, pool table, patio and I've never had a weak drink.
author: Matt C.

description: A really mellow spot. The few times I've been there, it's has been pretty empty, but that doesn't bother me.  No blaring techno mixes of pop songs, no dancing (that I've seen), and an outside patio! When there are a lot of people there, it's the perfect dive bar to go sit with friends and talk, which is what I like.
author: Sam S.

description: Great outdoor patio that you can sit on and smoke your lungs away, but could this place get more expensive?
author: Liz E.

description: What you don't about the Pilsner!!! The Best Mimosa's in SF on Sunday's From Mike and A Fabulous Margarita called JERZ (that sounds familiar) and worth the trip to SF.  Intense Pool playing Thursday night and pool lessons Saturday morning from Tim and Bryan. A very Mixed Crowd on Friday (torelance required!) after all STR8 people have to go someplace that's not boring.
author: Jerz Z.

description: I love the patio. Once I get there I don't really stray too far from the back unless to play a game of pool (which i suck at, but the Pilsner seems to be pretty shark-free) They also have a good selection of beer on tap. It's a good place to bring straight and gay friends alike.
author: Conor C.

description: Frankly the crowd at the Pilsner is friendly, gay, male, relatively courteous for a bar, more mature than the majority of the Castro and a really nice place to get a drink. They have Trumer on tap - yummy local beer - and a large selection of other beers and liquor. The bartenders have been nothing but nice to me and the back patio pretty much sells the place as one of the most stellar hang out bars in the area. I really enjoy this place as a meet up spot pre or post dinner at Chow or Home.
author: Jenifer G.

description: wait, this was a gay bar? i would have never known. most of the groups coming in were women and there was a good mix of people. and the tv was on sportscenter. anyways, they served ryan the biggest red bull/vodka ever so that always a plus. another plus for the phone booth. there was no phone in it, but you could go in there and actually here the person on the other line of your cell. unfortunately for me, i didnt want to hear the person on the other end and that kind of ended my night. although i was tired and wasted already anyways. good place
author: Andrew T.

description: Way, way over-priced bar with less than competent bar-tenders. Quite a nice crowd but what a rip-off.
author: Matt E.

description: I've been to this bar about 5 times in the last 12 months.  Let me tell you...it is DIRTY.  Each time I go there, the glasses are so disgusting.  Today was the worst...I was served 2 drinks in dirty glasses with crap all over it, and mysterious floating objects in them.  I asked for a straw and they didn't have any. only these cheap coffee stirrers.  Bartenders (after 4pm) were rude, and obviously lacking in customer service skills.  Wont be spending another dollar here.
author: ang b.

description: ive only been here once and i dont know how sober i was but i know i had a blast! pinball, yummy beers and the back patio is really cool!
author: Britney K.

description: We stopped by after dinner at Warakubune down the street.  They play fun music in here and the bathrooms are fairly clean.  The beers are cheap and there are plenty of places to sit.  It can get a bit loud in here even with a small crowd, but you are in a bar!
author: Brian L.

description: I requested my friends and I come here before venturing the rest of castro.  It was a mellow place to start the evening, which was what we wanted. I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would, but I could tell I would have liked it more under different circumstances (it was so freezing and the outdoor area was mostly rainsoaked).  The yelp reviews regarding the atmosphere were correct (no "scene" or attitude, just a chill place to hang out).  I knew I'd be having some heavier cocktails later in the evening, so I was stoked they had Beck's Premier Light and it wasn't too expensive.  Can't say too much about the place.  I'll have to go again to get a better feel.
author: J B.

description: one of the loveliest bar patios in the city...and usually good drink specials from what I've noticed.
author: Kerry L.

description: when we don't know where to go we go here, so it's like the default bar.  not a bad place, not annoying, but not great.  or this is the bar we start at to think about where we'll go next.  on a good night we might even end here because it's actually decent bar, i think i'm coming to realize that i really do like this place as i'm writing this review!  good drafts and your normal selection of drinks.   go puffins!!
author: Monk R.

description: Laid back bar with strong drinks and good beer. They have a nice back yard area, although it's been mighty smoky lately. I tend to pop a few dollars in the the juke box, then a few into the darts and pinball machines. A good place to hang out with friends because it's not super loud.
author: Michael H.

description: if i'm headed out with (gay male) friends, and we want a low key drink before dinner, the pilsner is it. this used to be our favorite birthday party venue- the big outdoor patio lends itself well to crowds, and the window seats are fun on weeknights- but i've somehow grown out of this now. still, the pilsner holds a special place in my heart.
author: oona m.

description: i was here. had two beers. or three. i can't remember. had a decently pleasant time. thought i was getting looked at a couple of times but was probably my imagination. upvote for the good times. will buy again.
author: Yan Biao B.

description: The second best (after the Lucky) actual bar in the Neighborhood.  If it had a better jukebox it might be tied for first.
author: Todd E.

description: The first time I ever went here some bum got in my face and started yelling at me. Luckily my later visits were much more enjoyable. The patio is great on nice days and the bartenders and other guys there are polite. It's a nice neighborhoody bar.
author: Michael G.
